text:
For me personally, I would say I think a lot about where SEO and great content intersect. That means paying attention to writing clear, descriptive headings and subheadings, including relevant related topics, writing to the user intent/user intents, thinking about internal and external linking to and from the page, writing for information gain, and how the piece of content fits into my inventory as a whole.

As Jeff said, the "SEO" stuff starts well before you start writing. It starts with a content audit, with building content briefs, research, etc.

elements.text:

As Jeff said, the "SEO" stuff starts well before you start writing. It starts with a content audit, with building content briefs, research, etc.

attachments.fallback:
[May 19th, 2021 7:56 AM] jenna491: I’m curious to know how you guys update old content? How do you pick what to update? What do you do to the piece?

Here’s what we do.

*Finding content to update*

We first start with pieces ranking ~5-10, or if it used to ranking #1. Here’s what we’ll do:

• Some rewrites
• Check to see if it matches search intent
• Use MarketMuse to find gaps compared to the competition
• Make it more digestible with a table of contents and FAQs
• Fix any SEO issues
• Improve formatting
• Add internal + external links
• Update stats to be more relevant/recent
• Add custom images and video
Then we’ll move onto pieces ranking 10+. There’s usually too many of these to count, so here’s how we prioritize, in order:

1. Commercial intent - if those readers are more likely to buy, prioritize
2. Similar for any middle of the funnel content
3. Highest volume + decent relevance
4. Everything else (so maybe there's some you don't waste time on because the volume and/or relevance don't really warrant the cost or resources)
As far as how we update this content, these pieces usually need substantial rewrites (like 50-100% rewritten). Then we do all of the optimizations I mentioned above. :)

If our articles are ranking in positions ~1-3, we usually don’t touch it too much, other than basic updates, fixing any issues that pop up, or updating dates.

Who’s next? I’d love to hear some ideas!:popcorn:

I’m curious to know how you guys update old content? How do you pick what to update? What do you do to the piece?

Here’s what we do.

*Finding content to update*

We first start with pieces ranking ~5-10, or if it used to ranking #1. Here’s what we’ll do:

• Some rewrites
• Check to see if it matches search intent
• Use MarketMuse to find gaps compared to the competition
• Make it more digestible with a table of contents and FAQs
• Fix any SEO issues
• Improve formatting
• Add internal + external links
• Update stats to be more relevant/recent
• Add custom images and video
Then we’ll move onto pieces ranking 10+. There’s usually too many of these to count, so here’s how we prioritize, in order:

1. Commercial intent - if those readers are more likely to buy, prioritize
2. Similar for any middle of the funnel content
3. Highest volume + decent relevance
4. Everything else (so maybe there's some you don't waste time on because the volume and/or relevance don't really warrant the cost or resources)
As far as how we update this content, these pieces usually need substantial rewrites (like 50-100% rewritten). Then we do all of the optimizations I mentioned above. :)

If our articles are ranking in positions ~1-3, we usually don’t touch it too much, other than basic updates, fixing any issues that pop up, or updating dates.

Who’s next? I’d love to hear some ideas!:popcorn:

text:
Jeff nailed the answer, so I'll just add to it.

When you're targeting specific keywords, particularly competitive ones, you can't think about creating just a single page with the expectation of ranking highly right off the bat. You have to surround that page with a cluster that targets different intents throughout the funnel.

I think I saw a discussion in here (can't remember where) where someone mentioned they had one page that was driving a significant amount of traffic. That page declined in rankings on its core topics, thus causing a traffic drop.

The idea is to support those pages with different intents and angles so you can stay competitive on those hard topics.

elements.text:

text:
It isn't *surprising* but the most frequent 80/20 is in the prioritization phase of content marketing.

So many mistakes are made and poor efficiency motions when a predictable process isn't in place for knowing the likelihood of success and amount of effort needed.

The easiest wins 80/20 are in intent mismatch and content enhancements

Intent mismatch - you are performing for a term where the page doesn't follow through on that intent, fix it or build and connect.

Content enhancements, make sure your currently performing page covers the target parts of the buyer journey comprehensively

^Those are the most repeatable quick wins

Hmm...maybe I'm just doing things wrong, but for me personally, I haven't had any successes without a ton of effort and pulling my hair out! :stuck_out_tongue:

One recent example of something that's really moved the needle is case studies. I produced a case study on how <http://monday.com|monday.com> used MarketMuse to level up its content production. That one case study has driven several great sales conversations and has directly led to sales already.

I'd say a good case study fits into that 80/20 model for me.

text:
The easiest to communicate is an elevation strategy, where I can assess --- for example -- a forum channel and see where the breadth of coverage, depth of coverage, frequency of high-quality posts, and historical momentum on a topic or collection of keywords is high.

Those concepts become candidates for me to apply editorial acumen and build to cover what the UGC didn't and fill gaps, to build comprehensive coverage where that would then act as a showcase for the UGC, and everything in between

text:
Hey <@U0227LHRTFG> and <@U01RVQFEFT9> - thank you for being here!

Google's goal is to prioritize useful content for its user. Lately I've seen a lot of people boasting success with "content velocity" - basically just putting out TONS of SEO optimized content outsourced from cheap labor off of freelance sites. Do you see this as a potential problem? I'm concerned this increases the pressure on people focusing on quality articles who can only put out 1 article per week, when there are teams putting out hundreds per week in similar niches.

text:
Great question Amanda. I hear you - even writing about something you know well can feel like you're just rehashing the same points.

One thing that keeps it fresh for me is interviewing subject matter experts on those well-trodden topics. It can be a great way to find fresh viewpoints and ideas on familiar material. It's also a great way to uncover some contrarian viewpoints and new angles.

I also like using MarketMuse's Compete application to find gaps in the coverage of a topic. It helps me find ways to talk about the subject matter in a way no one else is. Finding those gaps and filling them in not only makes your content differentiated, but helps you cover new ground.

text:
I hear you Justin, it can feel daunting when you see a competitor just pumping out lots of content.

I think as someone who's committed to content quality - as you seem to be! - you shouldn't be overly worried about the people using a content farm to pump out the classic "SEO content."

That's increasingly going to be a losing game, especially if they follow the typical approach of just frankensteining the top 10 results on a keyword together into one article.

Quality content at a manageable cadence that differentiates your business and is actually useful will be better in the long-run. Even if your competitors rank well, what are the chances that outsourced content is turning readers into buyers?

One of the best ways to gut check your content quality is to ask yourself:

"Could someone with a few thousand dollars to spend with a content farm replicate what I'm doing?"

If the answer is yes, your content is too generic.

How do you solve that?

- Write the content only you can. What does your team/company know better than anyone else? What point of view do you have that someone could reasonably argue for/against?
- Interview internal and external experts to dive deeper into a topic than what you could get just by searching Google.
- Find ways to write for information gain. What is no one else talking about?
- Collect interesting data from your customers/audience and use it to drive content ideas.
- Borrow content types and ideas from other industries and figure out how to apply them to your situation.

There's too much content out there to just rely on the classic "frankenstein the top 10 search results on a keyword together" approach. That's content farm thinking.

text:
It's dependant on your site's structure, the zone you are in (industry, affiliate landscape, competition landscape) and authoritativeness on the topics you cover.  I see them as three clubs in the bag with different benefits --- Content efficiency is the key metric.  How many create/update motions do they take, how many hit the predicted goals or KPIs.  Internal will tend to be higher than contributor than UGC, but the costs are often the opposite unless you are sourcing amazing experts....source awesome experts, pick the right targets, set expectations well and create single sources of truth for content (briefs) and you get the best of both worlds.

UGC is a wild horse, you have to harness the power.

text:
Most common mistakes:

1. Copying competitors
2. Copying powerful competitors who play by different rules that you
3. Listening to advice from people who optimize affiliate sites when your site is *not*
4. Thinking it is easy
5. Writing content that cannot be successful without planning and setting expectations that it is a long-term plan....thus then giving up and saying 'content isn't for me'
5a) they often say "content isn't for my space, product, location, site, company"

text:
It's this one: <https://blog.marketmuse.com/what-is-content-strategy/>

I completely rewrote this article last August after it had declined in rankings since its original publication date.

My goal wasn't to just write a single definition of "content strategy," but to dive deep into what content strategy really is.

I used our Search Intent Breakdown to really understand the user intents I needed to hit for a successful piece. Most people just look for the most common intent on page 1 of Google's search results page for their keyword. This is called "favored intent." Favored intent is often misleading because it distracts you from identifying other user intents.

In this case, our AI identified the user intents as 65% Know Simple and 35% Know. That means that while a definition of content strategy is essential for hitting the Know Simple intent, I needed to go deeper on the topic to satisfy the Know intent.

I used MarketMuse's Research application to understand the related topics I needed to cover, and I used our Compete application to find gaps in coverage that would differentiate my content. Powerful domains like HubSpot, Distilled, and even <http://Usability.gov|Usability.gov> were ranking highly here. I knew that if I just copied their articles that I would lose. I call this writing for information gain. You can read more about that here: <https://blog.marketmuse.com/content-writing-for-information-gain/>

The results? Shortly after writing this, we captured the featured snippet for terms like "content strategy" and "What is content strategy?"

I also learned that this approach of blending intents and adding a product angle is a great way to transform what could be just another TOFU article into something that moves people down the funnel. Users come to this page and often dive deeper into the site and check out the product pages/download something/start a trial. It's become a core page for us.

attachments.title: What is Content Strategy? (With Examples)
attachments.text: An easy way to understand what content strategy is, along with some real examples.
attachments.fallback: MarketMuse: What is Content Strategy? (With Examples)

attachments.title: Content Writing for Information Gain
attachments.text: Writing me-too content isn't the way to position yourself as a thought leader or rank well in Google. There's a good chance you're making that mistake. Here's how to avoid it.
attachments.fallback: MarketMuse: Content Writing for Information Gain

text:
You're not alone Hannah! We talk to so many content strategists who feel like they're constantly playing defense and never getting the chance to be proactive about content planning.

For me, I always start with what I already have in my content inventory. What pages do I have? What are they ranking for? What's missing from my cluster that I need to add to address more parts of the buyer's journey.

Like Jeff says, thinking in terms of quick wins, goals, and risk management can help you prioritize your efforts.

It sounds like you're focused on long term goals. I would think about the topics that are relevant to your business goals and use those as a springboard to find new ones.

text:
I think there will be a lot more AI augmentation on the content creation side. Right now, there are quite a few AI solutions that can help with research, building briefs, gauging content quality, etc. Actually creating original content with the help of AI seems to be next.

Like Jeff said, the low-end of the content creation market is going to get chopped off. Things like templated pages will be able to be generated at scale with AI and oversight of a human editor. It going back to what Justin asked about low-quality, high-volume outsourced content - if you're relying on that, you'll get crushed by AI.

At the higher end of the spectrum, AI will be used to kickstart drafts of high quality content. Human writers will start with that foundation and layer in their own expertise and points of view.

AI is great at doing the legwork of getting a draft to you. Humans are still superior at combinatory thinking - taking things that are wildly different and juxtaposing them. We have a point of view. AI may get close to that, but I don't see it being a total 1-1 replacement for a good human writer even in 5 years. I may be wrong though!

elements.text:
I think there will be a lot more AI augmentation on the content creation side. Right now, there are quite a few AI solutions that can help with research, building briefs, gauging content quality, etc. Actually creating original content with the help of AI seems to be next.

Like Jeff said, the low-end of the content creation market is going to get chopped off. Things like templated pages will be able to be generated at scale with AI and oversight of a human editor. It going back to what Justin asked about low-quality, high-volume outsourced content - if you're relying on that, you'll get crushed by AI.

At the higher end of the spectrum, AI will be used to kickstart drafts of high quality content. Human writers will start with that foundation and layer in their own expertise and points of view.

AI is great at doing the legwork of getting a draft to you. Humans are still superior at combinatory thinking - taking things that are wildly different and juxtaposing them. We have a point of view. AI may get close to that, but I don't see it being a total 1-1 replacement for a good human writer even in 5 years. I may be wrong though!
